content: The original question was about perception of time and relationship with memory. Can you explain how your model conceptualizes that? In your opinion how relevant is the perception of time to the phenomenon?

Sorry I'm confused how that's related to the message you're replying to

Have you experienced SR?

Edit: I saw in a different message that you said you have. In that case, my question for you is... Immediately after the realization did you have any weird physical sensation in your head? Some of the SR people I've talked to have unexplained physical sensations about where the brain would be. Mine was like a massless solid block lodged between my eyes and the back of my head. Someone else had a sphere. Someone else had a donut. Someone else had throbbing in the back of the head.
@jamie0773 can you clarify here what the word "it" is referring to? Is it "experience of the future" or "an outside world where the future will really happen with no relationship to me."
@pikachu_is_boss

I still think it's ambiguous when he uses the word "it" to either refer to "experience of the future" or "an outside world where the future will really happen with no relationship to me". I absolutely would agree that there is no such thing as experience of the future. But I still, and I would guess Jamie still acts as if the future will happen, just with no personal relationship with the future. This would mean that Jamie believes the future exists conceptually as a way to understand the world. I dunno though, probably worth pinging to ask him.

I think they've been imprecise with the way they described it and confused everyone (or something loosely like that). SR isn't a metaphysical claim about whether time exists or not. It's a claim about what your actual experience is, and therefore what you must actually be based on your experience. 

To be fair you can't prove the past or future really happened or will happen, but that's mostly unrelated to SR. Maybe Jamie means that "to me" the future doesn't exist, but Jamie doesn't act that way when he plans for the future. I would guess he still believes a concept of future describes the world, but that he has no experience of the future, and then describes that as "there is no future".

Okay I think we're getting to the root of what the problem is with the way I've been communicating. 

I accept that the future is real and that the future matters. It's just that I have no personal relationship with the future because I have no experience of it. It is not me who experiences the future I only experience now. I do not deny the existence of the future, I merely deny my personal relationship with it.

When are you ever not helping imaginary humans? Whenever you help someone you imagine that they will be better off in the future. There is no such thing as helping someone right now. The effect can only be in the future.

Why does anything matter? I dunno. Sorta just feels like it

I think it's a basic human instinct to want to help humans.

Yes
But the future imaginary people still matter

well its if i pull the needle out the effect still happens in the future, not an experience happening now
although i dunno if i would be lucid enough to be thinking anything at all if theres drugs already in my system

Yeah
Well in the present moment it's just a thought which isn't you

Yes I would (or at least I'd try) because I prioritize the future guys pleasure less than the further future guys withdrawal symptoms. 

I guess the difference is that it's sort of like a trolley problem where I have to actively pull the needle out rather than passively not go to the club.
Yes good summary
Woah! Cool
yeah i agree, that's a good way of putting it
yeah to be fair i didnt phrase that very precisely
That's all there ever was.
In my personal experience, SR mostly did not affect my discipline. For like a week it did but that may have had more to do with the meditation I was doing.

I have suddenly decided, "yeah fuck that guy let's get wasted on a Tuesday night." But I only exist in that moment. My only experience of getting wasted and having a sick time at the club is the thought of planning it. It's not me facing the consequences on Wednesday, but it's also not me having fun at the club Tuesday night. 

Planning for "my" consequences requires a misunderstood perception of time, but you do not become a pure hedonist because seeking "my" future pleasure also requires a misunderstood perception of time. It "cancels out", so to speak, and then mostly nothing happens.
true that

I suppose it certainly must have been someone. Beyond that I don't know. If you were try to identify that person though, it would have to be through thought, but that is exactly the misunderstanding that self-inquiry attempts to examine. 

Unsatisfactorily to the question answer: it just was
Seems like a highly valid question
oh lol
Yes I agree

This is my handwavy theory: Anxiety is an accidental hijacking of that ancient automatic circuit being activated when it doesn't need to be. 

I have no scientific basis for that theory, it sort of just sounds reasonable and nice.

Yes. 

To be a little nickpicky though, there is a difference between fear of the thought of death, which is anxiety, and bodily fear when the ancient automatic circuits in the brain go "oh fuck we need to not die right now". Anxiety is related to identification with a "me" whereas bodily fear is completely automatic and happens without any intellectual relationship with a "me". It's just a reflex.

I don't know why the self-image exists. Probably something to do with trying to form a coherent story through thought, even though trying to understand yourself through throught isn't possible in the first place.
yes
cool
Yeah this gets a little tricky with definitions. I think the only way to actually clarify the definition is to understand the whole thing. Unfortunately.

Suppose time stops. And then continues. Maybe time will double in speed. Maybe time slows to quarter speed. Maybe time skipped a few seconds. These are all changes in the continuity of time. Would you have any idea of that happening? Do you have an experience of that continuity? Does it even make sense to be able to have that experience?

It seems quite reasonable that the past exists. I dunno the universe could have started to exist exactly right now though. 

Right now I remember there being an experience of breakfast this morning. I can't be sure that this memory actually refers to something that really happened. Could be a false memory too, which happens, but that's unrelated.
is the memory not for the one who is recalling it right now?
I dunno I don't really think about it. So I guess it doesn't matter to me who collected the memory.
does the alien not also have literally the exact same subjective sense?
I think you should give an earnest answer to this question because it directly addresses the misunderstanding.

Well Jamie is the one who chose to use an alien as an analogy. I think the point is so that we intuitively know for sure the alien did not have a direct experience of a human past. 

I agree that every human more or less has the same type of memory function. 

Sure I have my own memories and you have yours. I am also not disputing that your entire memory bank appears to be from the same point of view of your body right now. I am disputing whether you have any direct personal relationship with your past experiences merely by virtue of having that memory.
The alien also claims to have experienced it. Why is your case stronger than the aliens' case?

What present information are you using to deduce that the past really happened? 
I'm not disputing that it didn't happen. It seems very reasonable that the past happened. I'm disputing whether you have any experience of the past at all. Functionally it's as if someone else has inhabited your body up until exactly right now.
I agree that it sounds very counterintuitive. It is very counterintuitive.

If I really did experience the way you recall the memory exactly the same then yes. The analogy only works if the experience of recalling the memory is actually literally exactly the same for both of us.
Well it isn't really your memory it's just memory. So yes

Thought of a counterargument that I will address 

You could say "but the body in the memory clearly reassembles my own far more than the aliens!" 

Then the alien gets his molecular shape shifting tech out and literally changes its body to be exactly the way the body in the memory is. "Checkmate" says the alien.

Put simply: The alien has no experience of your past (that is not a misunderstanding). The alien is experiencing your past the exact same way that you experience your own past. Therefore, you have no experience of you own past. 

You might say "But it was actually me there to experience it!" Then the alien would say "no it was me I remember being there! I clearly remember it was me!" You both are experiencing the same memory and therefore subjectively have the exact same strength of evidence to conclude "it was really me!" who was there. What would make your case stronger than the aliens?
